WHIT Argumentative/Explanatory (9-12).name: WHIT Argumentative/Explanatory Rubric (Grades 9-12)
WHIT Argumentative/Explanatory (9-12).description: High school writing rubric for argumentative or explanatory essays, aligned to Common Core and AP standards.
WHIT Argumentative/Explanatory (9-12).full_text: This rubric evaluates student writing based on thesis/focus, evidence and development, organization and cohesion, and expression and conventions.

thesis_focus.name: Thesis / Focus
thesis_focus.description: Clarity and strength of the central claim (argument) or controlling idea (explanation)

4: Establishes a precise, insightful, and consistently maintained thesis or controlling idea.
Shows originality or depth in framing the topic.
3: Presents a clear and appropriate thesis or focus that is maintained with minor lapses.
Clearly addresses the task.
2: Thesis or focus is present but vague, underdeveloped, or inconsistently maintained.
1: Lacks a clear central idea or claim.
May be off-topic or unfocused.

evidence_development.name: Evidence and Development
evidence_development.description: Use of evidence, elaboration, and analysis to support ideas

4: Provides relevant, specific, and well-integrated evidence.
Analysis is insightful and thoughtful.
In arguments, addresses counterclaims effectively.
3: Offers relevant and sufficient evidence with some explanation or reasoning.
Attempts counterclaim acknowledgment in arguments.
2: Evidence is minimal, vague, or uneven.
Little elaboration.
Counterclaims may be weak or missing.
1: Lacks sufficient or relevant evidence.
No meaningful elaboration or analysis.
Counterclaims absent.

organization_cohesion.name: Organization and Cohesion
organization_cohesion.description: Logical sequencing, transitions, and paragraph structure

4: Demonstrates clear and strategic organization.
Paragraphs flow logically with effective transitions and strong cohesion.
3: Shows overall clear organization with some effective transitions.
Generally cohesive.
2: Inconsistent or unclear structure.
Transitions may be basic or missing.
Flow may be uneven.
1: Disorganized or hard to follow.
No clear paragraphing or transitions.

expression_conventions.name: Expression and Conventions
expression_conventions.description: Style, tone, vocabulary, sentence fluency, and correctness

4: Demonstrates precise word choice, confident voice, and varied sentence structures.
Few, if any, grammatical or mechanical errors.
Voice suits purpose and audience.
3: Maintains a clear and appropriate tone.
Vocabulary and sentences are adequate.
Minor errors may be present but don‚Äôt impede clarity.
2: Limited variety in word choice or sentence fluency.
Style may be flat or inconsistent.
Frequent errors may disrupt flow.
1: Inappropriate tone, weak vocabulary, and numerous grammar/spelling errors that affect readability.

focus_purpose.name: Narrative Focus and Purpose
focus_purpose.description: Clarity and depth of theme, message, or storytelling purpose

4: Establishes a compelling and insightful narrative focus or theme.
Writing has a clear purpose and sustains reader interest throughout.
3: Establishes a clear narrative focus.
Purpose is evident and mostly sustained.
2: Somewhat unclear or inconsistent focus.
Theme or purpose may be vague or fade over time.
1: No clear narrative purpose or theme.
Lacks coherence or focus.

character_plot_setting.name: Development of Characters, Setting, and Plot
character_plot_setting.description: Development and interaction of narrative elements

4: Fully develops believable characters, vivid settings, and a well-structured plot.
Events unfold logically with attention to pacing and rising action.
3: Develops characters, setting, and plot with some depth.
Plot structure is generally clear and events mostly connect.
2: Limited development of characters or setting.
Plot may be basic, rushed, or disjointed.
1: Underdeveloped or confusing characters/plot/setting.
Narrative elements may be missing or incomplete.

organization_sequence.name: Organization and Sequence
organization_sequence.description: Structure, pacing, and use of transitions

4: Demonstrates strategic and purposeful organization.
Events follow a logical and engaging sequence with effective transitions and pacing.
3: Shows clear organization and appropriate pacing.
Some transitions used effectively.
2: Inconsistent structure or pacing.
Some transitions present but flow may be choppy.
1: Disorganized or unclear sequence of events.
Transitions missing or ineffective.

4: Uses descriptive, vivid language and a consistent narrative voice.
Sentence structures vary naturally.
Few to no grammar or spelling errors.
3: Language is clear and appropriate, with some variation and control of tone.
Minor errors do not interfere with understanding.
2: Basic or inconsistent language.
Some issues with tone, clarity, or grammar that affect fluency.
1: Frequent grammar, usage, or style issues.
Voice may be flat or inappropriate.
Errors hinder understanding.

Adequate introduction, conclusion, and flow

4: Thorough elaboration of evidence
Effective use of source material with clear citations
Precise language and comprehensive details
Effective elaborative techniques and style
Vocabulary appropriate for audience and purpose
3: Adequate elaboration and relevant evidence
General but appropriate citations and details
Mix of precise and general language
Generally appropriate vocabulary and style
2: Uneven elaboration or imprecise evidence
Weak or inconsistent citations
Repetitive or vague language
Weak elaborative techniques
Underdeveloped ideas
1: Minimal or irrelevant evidence
Little or no elaboration
Minimal or incorrect use of source material
Limited or ineffective vocabulary
Little evidence of style or clarity
NS: In a language other than English

2: Adequate command of conventions

Ignore fragmented presentation or alignment concerns in scoring

clear_focus_claim.name: üß† Clear Focus or Claim
clear_focus_claim.description: Strength and clarity of the main idea or thesis.

4: Clear and focused claim or main idea, strongly maintained throughout.
3: Clear claim or focus, mostly maintained.
2: Unclear or weak claim, inconsistently maintained.
1: Lacks a clear main idea or argument; may be off-topic or confusing.

supporting_evidence.name: üìö Supporting Ideas and Evidence
supporting_evidence.description: Quality and relevance of details, examples, and explanations.

4: Strong, relevant evidence and thoughtful explanations. May include counterclaims or well-chosen examples.
3: Sufficient evidence and explanation. Some reasoning is present.
2: Limited or weak evidence. Some ideas repeated or unclear.
1: Little or no supporting evidence. Writing is vague or unsupported.

organization_flow.name: üß≠ Organization and Flow
organization_flow.description: Structure, transitions, and progression of ideas.

4: Logical structure with clear intro, body, and conclusion. Smooth transitions.
3: Mostly organized and easy to follow. Some transitions used.
2: Some organization but jumps between ideas. Limited transitions.
1: Disorganized or hard to follow. No clear structure.

language_conventions.name: ‚úçÔ∏è Language, Style, and Conventions
language_conventions.description: Grammar, sentence fluency, word choice, and tone.

4: Strong word choice, sentence variety, mostly error-free. Tone fits purpose.
3: Generally clear with few errors. Some sentence variety. Appropriate tone.
2: Frequent errors or repetitive sentence structure. Tone may be off.
1: Major errors or unclear writing throughout. Hard to understand.

focus_purpose.name: Focus and Purpose
focus_purpose.description: How clearly the narrative establishes and maintains a purpose or theme.

4: Narrative focus is clear and engaging throughout.
The purpose or theme is thoughtfully developed.
3: Focus is mostly clear with some sense of purpose.
Theme is present and mostly consistent.
2: Focus may be vague or shift during the piece.
Theme or purpose is underdeveloped.
1: No clear focus or theme is evident.
Writing may be off-topic or confusing.

character_plot_setting.name: Characters, Plot & Setting
character_plot_setting.description: How well the writer builds the world of the story.

4: Characters, setting, and events are well-developed and connected.
Plot shows logical progression and creative details.
3: Basic development of characters, setting, and plot.
Events mostly make sense and connect.
2: Some parts underdeveloped or unclear.
Plot may be disjointed or rushed.
1: Characters, setting, or events are confusing or missing.
Narrative structure is unclear.

organization_sequence.name: Organization & Sequence
organization_sequence.description: How well the story flows from beginning to end.

4: Clear structure with strong sequencing and transitions.
Pacing fits the story and holds interest.
3: Structure is mostly logical with some transitions.
Pacing is generally appropriate.
2: Inconsistent structure or weak transitions.
Some parts may feel rushed or drag.
1: Disorganized or confusing flow.
Events may not follow a logical order.

language_conventions.name: Language & Conventions
language_conventions.description: Use of language, grammar, sentence variety, and mechanics.

4: Strong, vivid language and well-controlled sentences.
Very few errors in grammar or spelling.
3: Language is clear with some variety.
Minor errors do not affect understanding.
2: Simple or repetitive language.
Several errors may impact readability.
1: Frequent grammar or spelling errors.
Language is unclear or distracting.
